Preparing for a job interview?

Look for clues in the job description to find the types of questions the interviewer could ask. Specifically, look for the pain points of the job and specific qualifications that they may be looking for.

Take the job requirements and flip them into behavioral interview questions. 

Here are a few examples: 

- Find, engage and activate passive candidates through the use of Boolean, LinkedIn and alternative search techniques (sourcing technical recruiter job description)

üîÜ Tell me about a time that you used Boolean, LinkedIn or alternative search techniques to find a hard to find candidate. How did you find the job seeker and walk me through how you built a relationship with them.

- Mitigate risks to maximize product availability while minimizing supply chain costs with specific and actionable recommendations. (Supply manager job description)

üîÖ Tell me about a specific time that you were able to mitigate risks while maximizing product availability and minimizing supply chain costs. What were the results?

Your ability to tell stories in the interview will help you connect with the hiring managers.

Are you an executive job seeker who feels that ageism is impacting your search? 

Here is a quick rundown on the problem and how you can combat it. 

Ageism is when an employer discriminates against an applicant based on their age. 

If you are well qualified, they are NOT concerned about your ability to do the job.

The employer is concerned about potential issues that could arise AFTER they hire you. 

1) Will you be easy to manage? 

2) Will you bring the same level of engagement as a less experienced employee who is anxious to prove themselves? 

3) Are you a flight risk when a better opportunity comes along? 

If you are trying to combat ageism by focusing on your qualifications, you may not be addressing the right issues.
